column2: tomsan324, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
Mel B, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have extremely painful endometriosis and have tried many different pain management options over the last 8 years. This is the third time I've been prescribed vicodin and each time it has been effective to manage my breakthrough pain. I also take an extended release ultram and cymbalta  daily to help with pain. If addiction is something you're concerned about, I would recommend doing some of your own research and talking to your doctor. There is such a thing as being dependent on a medication and it is not the same thing as being an addict. There is a really great article on this website about long term pain management and addiction that could help a lot of the misinformed out there. I have had a few side effects from the vicoden including itching and constipation. I take psyllium husks powder daily and it has just about eliminated the constipation. Overall, vicoden has been an excellent treatment for my pain, though it doesn't always take away my pain for the full 4-6 hours between doses.

column2: browne57, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: My Rheumatology Dr has prescribed Vicodin 5/500 as a first time pain management drug and have been taking it for two months now. constipation and sweating bouts that come at odd times daily are the only side effects so far. I get good relief from joint pain over the daily routine of activity taking 3 times daily as prescirbed.It allows me to walk and do general life activities which were eluding me before. The FDA is making drug manufacturers reduce the tylenol amounts in these drugs soon i.e Vicodin,percocet,etc and a good idea for those that need pain relief but don't tolerate tylenol or it's effectiveness in these combinations.I recommend trying the Fentanyl patch 25mcg evey 72 hrs if other pain meds become ineffective as it gives good long acting relief without all the tylenol.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
USAFSGT, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I was prescribed this drug approx. 5 years ago. I use it for breakthrough pain. I take morphine SR 30mg q12h for my chronic, severe, pain as a result of breaking my neck and damaging my spinal cord. The Vicodin is used q6-8 hrs as needed for pain above and beyond my chronic suffering. I was a medic in the USAF prior to my injury so I know a bit about the pharmacology of this drug. If you use it post surgically or for an acute (short term) injury you need to exercise caution. If you suffer from chronic pain the addiction potential is minimal. Addiction occurs by the drug reaching the "pleasure centers" of the brain. In chronic pain it never, or extremely rarely reaches those centers. It is diverted to the source of the pain instead. You should not be afraid to take it as prescribed and needed. You must ry to stay ahead of pain. Once the pain has arisen it is somewhat futile to chase it trying to get relief.

I know addiction is a problem but I have a disease that will progress until the day I die,so I am in a catch 22. Its a tough call. I can only police myself and consult with my doctor.

column2: annie, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Took first after dental work, and worked well. Tried it for migraines,and it works fairly well alone...diminishes migraine pain within 2 hours if I sit up the whole time, but if I add 2 acetominophen/aspirin/caffeine tabs (OTC) I get effective relief of migraine within 30-45 min. With very severe migraine, sometimes take alprazolam (prescribed for me) also, for anxiety about pain.  So far, no side effects. Best treatment for my migraines I've found...after battling them for over 40 years, with dozens of meds.  They are less frequent with my taking verapamil prophylactically for several years, but when I have one, it's a doozie! 72 hours long,until I stumbled on this combo.

column2: freebornman20042aol.com, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on vicoden 500. For lower lumbar back chronic pain. I have had 2 MRI's I have bulging disc's at L/4-L/5-S/1 with sciatica flare up's. The buldging rains from 3 milameters to 7 milameters. Also suffer from muscle spasms & sharp pain down my left leg to my foot. I have been on the same dosage for 8 year's. To me it seem's it just is not working as well as it did at 1st. I feel I need my meds. up graded to a stronger strength I truely believe my tolerance has raised to the effect of the med & I need a stronger dose.?? My Dr. is trying to put off lower back surgery as long as possible. I have had 5 epideral steriod injection's in the past. I just really feel I need a stronger dosage to help to relieve the chronic pain. I am in pain daily on a scale of 1 to 10. I live with about a pain scale of 5 daily & when I have a flare up it jump's right to a 10. I really feel I need the vicoden es or something stronger.? I can't seem to understand why my Dr. or other Dr.'s just don't seem to want to give a stronger dosage or med to relieve the pain & I have 2 MRI.'s to prove the back problems. It just seem's it is harder for a mid aged male to get the pain meds.? Also 1 year ago I lost my best friend & hero my Dad a 37 year City Captain of our Fire Dept. I was a live in caregiver & Dad was a big man, I have done alot of heavy lifting to help out Dad which I know cannot be good on my lower back.? I would gladly accept any solutions anyone has to offer.!!

column2: seashell, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: This drug works very well BUT IT IS AN ADDICTIVE DRUG!!! I have been taking this fro 4 years due to 13 reconstructive surgeries. I am now trying to get off of it (against medical advice) and it is HORRIBLE!If doinf this on your own (not recomended) you have to ween yourself off a little at a time and it is pure HELL! Only take as long as necessary and only as prescribed!

column2: Whitefeather, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I've been taking the generic equivalent of Vicodin ES by my neurologist's recommendation for the last 11 months. It has been most effective in easing the pain and stiffness associated with atrophy from late term multiple sclerosis (relapsing-remitting). I take 2 of the 7.5mg  tablets a day and have found it works faster on an empty stomach, lifting the tight squeezing pain from the joints in my legs and hands within 20-30 minutes. I have tried Percocet and Ultram as well but neither were  as fast or as effective as Hydrocodone. I do not drink alcoholic beverages, but use caution if you do (or stop entirely) if your doctor prescribes this as it can be dangerous.

column2: dizzy_dee_1966, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have had several surgeries since 1996 and have been on lortab off and on they work great to control my pain

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years
column9: Anyone who continues to use this drug beyond its prescribed perameters has a dependency issue brewing. Not that dependency is neccesarily a bad thing but the patient will soon turn to purchasing the drug on the street and the abuse of the drug will increase.  Why is it ok to be addicted to coffee or cigarettes but not ok to be addicted to an opiode based drug??

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: After having a ventral hernia surgery I was prescribed Lortab for the pain 1 pill every 3 hours or as needed I found that this made me constipated to the point that I thought I was going to die.  Having experienced using vicodin for pain relief before hand for a abscess tooth I asked to be put on the Vicodin ES Brand Name Not (generic Im allergic to the fillers, it caused a itchy rash) which worked surprisingly better.  took the pain away and left me able to function normally. I only noticed two side effects while on this medication mood swings and hyperactivity which kept me from sleeping a full eight hours every single night.  I took this product for one month and had no addiction or withdrawls to the medication. I was able to sleep a full 8 hours every night.  a month after that the hernia mysteriously came back, Surprise Surprise Surprise, I had to go through three months of tests to be told the hernia recurred and vicodin ES got me through pain.  Two weeks ago I had my second surgery to remove the Bard ventralex patch that failed after only two months and was probably implanted inncorrectly from the beginning. Post surgery: I was again prescribed lortab even though I protested this medication and explained to the nurse that that medication does not work for me.  She said it is the same product as the vicodin ES and despite my argumentative state and resistance to accepting the prescription, I was sent home to start my recovery.  for two days I took the lortab every three hours as prescribed. I had  very little pain relief and and within two days again I had constipation that I thought was going to kill me.  I called and had the doctor write a prescription for the vicodin and from the first hour after I took the medication I started getting some relief.  Although the sleeplesness has returned I am able to function and get thourgh my days almost painfree,  but not mood swing free.  Allways a negative for the positive but in this case I would rather be pain free.
